These settings are included for experimentation and any changes made to them have the potential to cause instability, crashes, data loss or hardware failures.\n\nWe request you do not file bug reports if any of these settings have been changed from the defaults.
Change CPU governor and clock speed
Restore the processor settings on boot
Restore the I/O scheduler settings on boot
Customize the usage of memory to alter system performance
Compress memory for increased virtual capacity (requires reboot)
KSM reduces physical memory requirements and improves performance
Purging of bitmap memory assets allows the freeing of more RAM when needed (requires reboot)
Better graphics performance, but lower quality and may cause visual artifacts (requires reboot)
Notice:\nAs the start volume is set higher than the ringer volume, the ring tone will be played using the ringer volume.
Writing a profile to a NFC tag allows for tapping the tag to select the profile. Tapping a second time will select the previously selected profile.
This NFC tag refers to an unknown profile. Attaching this NFC tag to an existing profile will allow for selecting the profile in the future.
Intelligently vary the backlight brightness of the display and help maximize battery life

Changing this setting may be against your state or government laws.\n\nIn selecting \'OK\' below, you acknowledge this warning and waive, indemnify and hold harmless CyanogenMod and its contributors from all legal liabilities.
All brightness levels will be reset to their default settings.

How is brightness calculated? 

 The brightness curve is calculated by performing a cubic spline interpolation on a given number of control points. It's not a 'bucket-type' calculation where screen brightness will stay constant for a specific range of ambient brightness. That way, small changes in ambient brightness do not cause a large jump in screen brightness; however, it can be a little hard to predict the exact consequences of changing control points.
 To help with that, a preview of the calculated curve can be examined. Please note that the preview shows the curve in logarithmic scale, so that all control points can be shown distinctively. When using a linear scale, it wouldn't be possible to distinguish the tendentially more important control points in the lower range of ambient brightness. 

 How to edit the brightness curve? 

 Each line in the brightness list corresponds to one control point of the brightness curve. To edit the brightness level of the point, you can use the slider present in each line. The screen brightness will be changed accordingly while touching the slider to give a preview of the light level.
 Additional options are available by long-pressing a line. By selecting 'Edit', you can both edit the ambient brightness level of the control point as well as manually input the desired screen brightness. Selecting 'Split' allows you to to duplicate one line into two in order to insert additional control points. 'Remove' deletes the selected line.
When unlocked, include options in the power menu for rebooting into recovery or bootloader

These settings are included for experimentation and any changes made to them have the potential to cause instability, crashes, data loss or hardware failures.\n\nWe request you do not file bug reports if any of these settings have been changed from the defaults.
The time between wifi scans when no stored access points are available
Windows Manager\'s max events per second
This is a runtime value that controls the number of events the system will allow in a second
The amount of time from when the system registers an incoming phone call until the ringer
This controls the size of the cache the Dalvik VM has access to
We should look because knowing is half the battle
*WARNING* if you change this value it will add the needed values to your build.prop if they are not already present
When you are in-call screen is off when the device moves away from your face this delay value controls how long before screen turns on

Swipe to view - Click to choose
Make sure you follow the steps one-by-one and complete each one before proceeding to the next.
1. Change LCD Density to stock value
Tablets and older phones use 160. Most phones use 240. Galaxy Nexus uses 320 by default.
Come back here after the reboot and complete the rest of the steps!
"Market data couldn't be cleared, please clear it yourself!"
Press back when done to return here.
"Couldn't open the market! If you're sure it's installed, open it yourself from the launcher."
5. Change density to whatever you like!
If you ever have compatibility issues with the market, be sure to return here and repeat the process.
"Changing your LCD density can cause unexpected app behavior. If you encounter market app incompatibility please return here and restart the process from step 1."

When Privacy Guard is enabled, the app will not be able to access personal data such as contacts, messages or call logs.
When enabling Privacy Guard for a built-in app, the app will not be able to access or provide personal data. This may cause other apps to misbehave.
Enable by default for newly-installed apps
Manage which apps have access to your personal data
No apps with relevant permissions are installed

In this screen you can choose for which apps Privacy Guard should be active by simply tapping on them. Selected apps will not be able to access your personal data, such as contacts, messages or call logs. Long pressing on an entry opens the app details screen for that app.\n\nBy default built-in apps are not shown. If you want to show them or filter apps to show only the ones requesting access to personal data by their permissions, select the respective options in the menu.
You don\'t have any blacklisted numbers. Add an entry by touching the Add (+) button.
To blacklist calls and/or messages from certain numbers, enable the blacklist.
Incoming calls and messages from phone numbers in the blacklist will be blocked
Don\'t block calls from private numbers
Don\'t block calls or messages from numbers not in the contact list
Block incoming %s from numbers not in the contact list
Use . as a wildcard and * for repetition. E.g. 123.* blocks numbers starting with 123 and .*123.* blocks numbers containing 123
Do you want to remove this blacklist entry?

You are about to enable SEAndroid, an advanced security mechanism, on your device.

This option exists for debugging purposes only, and it is very likely that your device isn't fully ready for it, which may cause parts (or all) of your hardware to block or hang.

Are you sure you want to proceed?
